case_vignette: A 26-year-old nursing home staff presents to the emergency room with complaints of palpitations and chest pain for the past 2 days. She was working at the nursing home for the last year but has been trying to get into modeling for the last 6 months and trying hard to lose weight. She is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol on weekends with friends. On examination, she appears well nourished and is in no distress. The blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg and the pulse is 118/min. An ECG shows absent P waves. All other physical findings are normal.
question: What is the probable diagnosis?

trial_0.vignette_mcq: The probable diagnosis is Atrial Fibrillation or other supraventricular tachycardia due to the absent P waves on ECG and the palpitations. Anorexia nervosa may cause arrhythmias but the absence of P waves is not a typical finding in this condition. Hashimoto thyroiditis and Graves' disease are thyroid disorders and do not typically present with palpitations and absent P waves. Factitious thyrotoxicosis is a rare condition where a person intentionally produces or alters their bodily fluids to mimic the symptoms of hyperthyroidism, and it is unlikely to present with palpitations and absent P waves.

[Hashimoto thyroiditis is a condition characterized by the immune system attacking the thyroid gland, leading to hypothyroidism. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by restrictive eating and excessive weight loss. Factitious disorder (mimicking angina) is a condition where a person intentionally produces or feigns symptoms of angina or other cardiac conditions. Graves' disease is a condition characterized by hyperthyroidism and immune system attack on the thyroid gland.]
